The “Normal Pathology” Thesis

Key Premise
Far-right parties represent abnormal values alien to Western democratic culture



Research question derived:
“Under what extreme conditions do abnormal attitudes emerge?”

Economic crisis
Social breakdown
Immigration surge
Political corruption





Implication:
Far-right success = systemic crisis, pathological deviation from democratic norms


This was the dominant approach until Mudde (2010).
Key features: 1. Far-right attitudes seen as deviant 2. Success requires extreme conditions 3. Focus on why SOME people develop these attitudes 4. Crisis as necessary condition
Examples: - Golden Dawn = crisis (fits) - But: Austria FPÖ 1999 = no crisis (doesn’t fit) - Sweden SD 2010 = prosperity (doesn’t fit)
The evidence from Weeks 2-6 challenges this framework.

Summary: The Drivers of Far-Right Support



1. Beyond “Protest”
Far-right voting reflects stable ideological preferencesrather than just temporary frustration.


2. Economic vs. Cultural Grievances

Economic: Insecurity and relative deprivation fuel support.
Cultural: Values regarding gender, cosmopolitanism, and multiculturalism are often the primary drivers.





3. Cultural Grievances vs. Contact

Cultural Threat: Perceptions of threat can drive support.
Contact/Cosmopolitanism: Local interaction can reduce prejudice.
Geographic Variance: Patterns in Eastern Europe and Germany suggest complex “threat” stories.



4. So what then?
Demand is necessary, but is it sufficient?

The Inverted Puzzle



Should favor far-right breakthrough:


Economic transition shock (1990s)
High corruption & weak institutions
Brain drain & demographic decline
Refugee crisis (2015-16)



Yet historically (2000-2020):


Separate far-right parties were weak or collapsed (e.g., LPR in Poland, Jobbik in Hungary).
Paradox: Nationalism was high, but “Far-Right Parties” were low.
Mechanism: Mainstream parties (Fidesz, PiS) radicalized and “stole” the space.


The New Reality (2023+): The “containment” has failed. New, insurrectionary forces are breaking through (Romania, Poland’s Konfederacja).

text:
Patterns We Observe in Western Europe



Demand-Side Patterns

Timing varies dramatically: A 30-year span exists between breakthroughs (e.g., France 1984 vs. Germany 2017) despite similar socio-economic conditions.
Historical legacies: National histories, such as the post-WWII stigma in Germany, shape the “possibility space” for far-right emergence.
Mobilization gaps: While anti-immigrant or anti-elite attitudes are widespread, parties vary significantly in their ability to mobilize them into votes.



Supply & Strategic Patterns

Diverse trajectories: Party development varies across the region: stable (France), volatile (Austria), fragmented (Netherlands), delayed (Germany), and isolated (Belgium).
The Moderation Premium: Political success correlates with programmatic moderation; open extremism is typically linked to failure.
Mainstream responses: Outcomes are shaped by how established parties react, ranging from cordon sanitaire to accommodation or position theft.






Takeaway: Far-right success is not automatic: it depends on how parties and mainstream actors structure similar grievances.

Welcome students to the final lecture. Today we move beyond our Eurocentric focus. The goal is to test if the “Demand/Supply” framework we’ve used for 9 weeks holds up globally. We’ll look at the ‘Fourth Wave’ (Mudde), the ‘Immigration Paradox’ (Jonge et al. 2024), and how the ‘Other’ is defined in different contexts.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Beyond Europe: The “Fourth Wave”


The “European” Lens: - Traditionally focused on Western Europe (1980s-90s) - Expansion to Eastern Europe (2000s) - Heavy emphasis on nativism and immigration

The “Global” Turn: - Rise of strongmen in the Americas, Asia, and the Global South - Heterogeneity: Different drivers (crime, religion) under the same “umbrella” - Transnationalization: Global networks like CPAC and the Foro de Madrid



European Lens: Remind them of the ‘Third Wave’ (post-WWII to 2000s). It was mostly about fringe parties becoming challengers.
Global Turn: Mudde argues we are in the ‘Fourth Wave’ where the far-right is mainstreamed and global.
Key Question: Is a party in India (BJP) comparable to one in Sweden (SD)? We need to look at the ‘Umbrella’ concept.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Nationalism: The Global Umbrella

The Conceptual Problem:

Nativism (xenophobic/ethnic) is central to the European far-right (Mudde, 2007).
But does it travel? In Latin America, immigration levels are often low.

Reframing the Core (Jonge et al., 2024):

Instead of strict nativism, Nationalism serves as the broader global umbrella.
Global North: Focus on external threats (immigrants, Islam).
Global South: Focus on internal threats (corrupt elites, criminals, “anti-nationals”).
Key Insight: The “Other” shifts, but the exclusionary logic remains.




This slide is based on the 2024 Nations & Nationalism exchange.
Point to emphasize: In Europe, the ‘Other’ is the outsider coming in (horizontal exclusion). In LatAm, the ‘Other’ is often the ‘traitor’ inside—the corrupt politician or the criminal (vertical/internal exclusion).
Nationalism is the glue: “The People” are defined against “The Non-People” (whoever they may be).

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Mapping the Global Rise



Look at the scale of these victories.
Bukele (El Salvador): 84% in 2024. This is ‘hegemonic’ support, unlike the 20-25% we see in Europe.
Trump: Notice the steady rise in popular vote share (46% -> 49%).
BJP: Remarkable stability in a parliamentary system with over 30% vote share, translating to massive seat majorities.
Key Takeaway: We are looking at ‘Majority-building’ projects, not just protest voting.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Transnational Networks

The Foro de Madrid (2020):

Led by Vox (Spain).
Narrative: Fighting the “threat of communism” (Grupo de Puebla).
Goal: Consolidate the “Iberosphere” through shared conservative values.

CPAC (Conservative Political Action Conference):

Originally US-centric, now a global network (Brazil, Japan, Hungary).
A hub for “copy-paste” electoral tactics and rhetoric.




The far-right is Internationalist.
The Foro de Madrid: Replaces the ‘anti-immigrant’ focus with ‘anti-communism’ (Sino-Soviet/Cuban influence tropes) to unite Spain and LatAm.
Copy-Paste Tactics: Mention how Bolsonaro used Trump’s playbook (questioning electronic voting machines) almost verbatim.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Regional Puzzles

Observation: Sudden rise of Milei (Argentina), Bolsonaro (Brazil), Bukele (El Salvador).
The “Immigration Paradox” (Jonge et al., 2024):

Unlike Europe, immigration is not the primary driver.
Instead: Crime, corruption, and economic collapse.
The “Other” is the internal enemy (criminals, corrupt politicians) rather than the migrant.

Religion: Massive role of the Evangelical Church (Doğan, 2025).



Immigration Paradox: Why do these parties win without ‘migration crises’?
In Brazil/Salvador, Crime is the ‘demand’ equivalent of immigration in Europe. The ‘Iron Fist’ (Bukele) is the product.
Religion: In LatAm, the Evangelical shift is a massive ‘Supply’ factor. It provides the moral infrastructure that parties used to lack.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Case Study: Brazil (Bolsonaro)

Organization: Weak party structure, highly personalist.
Narrative: “Brazil above everything, God above all.”
Welfare Strategy:

Inclusionary Logic: Used Bolsa Família (Auxílio Brasil) to maintain support among the poor.
Exclusionary Logic: Symbolic targeting of “enemies” (LGBTQ+, Leftists, NGOs).

Democracy: Erosion through military co-optation and institutional bypass.



Bolsonaro’s Paradox: He is neoliberal in rhetoric but expansionist in welfare for ‘his’ people.
Inclusionary vs Exclusionary: This is a key theoretical concept. He included the ‘working poor’ economically while excluding them culturally if they didn’t fit the ‘patriotic’ mold.
Compare with Europe’s ‘Firewall’—in Brazil, the military was the support structure.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
text:
Case Study: Argentina (Milei)

The “Anarcho-Capitalist” Far-Right:

High emphasis on market radicalism vs. the “Casta” (political elite).
Distinct from Europe: Not “welfare chauvinism” (protecting state benefits for natives) but a rejection of the state itself due to failure/corruption.

The Market as the “People”:

Redefining the people through economic freedom rather than just national identity.
A radical shift from the traditional Peronist populist model.




Milei is unique. Most far-right parties like the state (to control borders/welfare). Milei wants to destroy it (the chainsaw).
The ‘Casta’: This is his ‘Other’. It’s an anti-elite populism taken to the extreme.
Why did it work? 100%+ inflation. When the state fails completely, the ‘Demand’ side shifts from ‘protecting the state’ to ‘destroying the state’.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
section: The USA: American Exceptionalism No More?
text:
The USA: American Exceptionalism No More?

Cas Mudde (2022): The US is “Europeanizing” in its far-right manifestations.
Mainstreaming: The Republican Party has been “captured” by far-right frames.
The “Hungarian Model”: Explicit comparisons between Trump and Orbán.

Judicial capture
Media harassment
Discrediting electoral integrity




For decades, we thought the US was immune because of its two-party system.
Mainstreaming: Instead of a third party rising (like AfD), the far-right took over a mainstream party (GOP).
The Orbán Link: Mention how CPAC met in Budapest. Trump explicitly praises Orbán’s ‘illiberal democracy’.

title: Global Patterns & Summary
section: India: The BJP and Religious Populism
text:
India: The BJP and Religious Populism

The “Hindutva” Ideology:

Defining “The People” as Hindu; secularism as an “elite” imposition.

The “Others”: Muslims, “anti-nationals” (academics, NGOs, liberals).
Welfare & Inclusion:

The BJP uses social schemes to integrate lower-caste Hindus while explicitly excluding religious minorities (McDonnell & Cabrera, 2019).




Hindutva: This is the ‘Nationalism’ umbrella. It merges religion and citizenship.
Digital Populism: The BJP is perhaps the most advanced party in the world in terms of WhatsApp/Social Media mobilization.
Comparison: Like the French RN, the BJP tries to look ‘moderate’ on economics (development) while remaining radical on identity.

Demand (The Fuel):

Three Questions

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
section: Why BNP Failed: Locked in Extremism
text:
Why BNP Failed: Locked in Extremism

Geographic concentration

563,743 votes (2010) but only 3.8% nationally
88 council seats (2005) on just 4.3% vote share
Support heavily clustered in a few local strongholds

Extremism trap

Neo-Nazi imagery kept party on the hardline fringe
Could hit 16% in local “true believer” areas
But could never reach 4%+ nationally (repelled moderates)

Unable to moderate

Unlike UKIP, couldn’t soften message without losing core identity
Fascist heritage blocked “respectable” rebranding
Strategically stuck: need extremism to survive, but extremism blocks growth

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
text:
Why UKIP Succeeded: Strategic Repositioning

Framing shift:

BNP: “British culture threatened by non-white immigrants” (racialist)
UKIP: “Britain’s sovereignty threatened by Brussels” (Eurosceptic)

Image matters:

BNP: Perceived Neo-Nazi associations, skinhead base, paramilitary
UKIP: Farage in suits, professional media, mainstream

Anti-immigration reframed:

BNP: “Racial threat” (extremist appeal only)
UKIP: “Public service pressure, population control” (moderate appeal)

Result:

Same underlying demand
Completely different supply
By 2015, access to roughly 6.8x more voters

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
section: The Paradox: 13.2% Votes, 1 Seat, Won Brexit
text:
The Paradox: 13.2% Votes, 1 Seat, Won Brexit

Electoral system effect

2014 EP (PR): 26.6% → 24 MEPs
2015 GE (FPTP): 13.2% → 1 MP
Same electorate, different rules → radically different representation

Electorally weak, but policy victory

Only 1 seat in Westminster
Yet: Pushed Conservatives into promising a referendum (2013)
Yet: Helped set the agenda for the 2016 Brexit vote
→ Electoral marginality ≠ policy irrelevance

Key insight

Non‑electoral pathways of influence: agenda‑setting, intra‑party pressure, media
Far‑right success is not just about seats, but about shaping options

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
section: Why UKIP Declined, Why Reform Emerged (Same Demand, New Vessel)
text:
Why UKIP Declined, Why Reform Emerged (Same Demand, New Vessel)


UKIP 2010-2015 - Breakthrough and fulfilment


Forced EU referendum onto agenda
Became main vehicle for Brexit demand
Policy goal achieved in 2016 → mission accomplished


UKIP 2016-2019 – Redundancy and collapse


Core issue (EU membership) removed from agenda
Leadership crises and party infighting
Vote share and organisation rapidly disintegrate



Reform 2022-2024 – Successor party


Farage returns with new vehicle (Clacton 2024)
Conservative government instability (Brexit fallout, Covid, Truss, etc.)
Rising Conservative voter dissatisfaction on immigration, taxes, “betrayed Brexit”
Same underlying demand (nationalist, anti‑establishment, anti‑immigration)
New credible supply to channel it


Pattern

Underlying demand is structural and durable
Party vehicles are temporary and recyclable (roughly every 15–20 years)

Reform Breaks into Scotland: Holyrood Constituency Vote

Holyrood constituency vote intention, 2022-2026Source: Scottish Election Study, Scottish Opinion Monitor
Question: Why NOW? Scotland uses PR (not constrained by FPTP). This is pure demand/supply question.

Before Oct 2024: Reform likely clustered in “Other”—so emergence is partly definitional (added as option) but also real (rapid growth once visible).

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
section: Why Scotland’s Political Space Opens Now (Vampa et al. Forthcoming in Political Studies)
text:
Why Scotland’s Political Space Opens Now (Vampa et al. Forthcoming in Political Studies)


20 years (1998-2018): SNP-Tory symbiosis on constitutional issues


SNP: “Vote for us for independence”
Conservatives: “Vote for us to defend the Union and deliver Brexit”
Independence vs. Union becomes the dominant cleavage, structuring party competition and voter alignments
Other conflicts (immigration, tax, anti‑establishment sentiment) are submerged beneath the sovereignty question



Post‑2019/2024: Symbiosis breaks down


SNP weakened: leadership crisis, indyref fatigue, governing wear‑and‑tear
Scottish Conservatives lose credibility: UK‑wide scandals, Brexit delivery, and UK “muscular unionism” alienate voters
Salience of the constitutional issue stops rising and begins to diffuse into wider frustration with both camps


Result


Constitutional polarisation erodes to let new player, like the anti‑establishment, anti‑SNP party enter the field (Reform) under proportional rules

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
section: Demand is Structural, Supply is Contingent
text:
Demand is Structural, Supply is Contingent

Same demand, different supply vehicles:

2010: BNP (563k votes, extremist) vs UKIP (919k votes, sovereigntist)
Underlying economic/cultural anxiety is similar
Distinct framings → divergent electoral trajectories

Supply parties recycle (~15-20 years):

BNP peaks mid‑2000s → hits extremism ceiling, collapses
UKIP peaks 2015 → achieves Brexit goal, becomes redundant
Reform rises post‑2022 → reactivates same reservoir of discontent
Parties are disposable vessels; underlying demand is durable

Supply spreads to new regions:

England: BNP → UKIP → Reform as successive carriers
Scotland: long blocked by constitutional salience → opening after SNP–Tory symbiosis breaks
Same demand, different institutional and territorial opportunity structures

ESS Demographics: Who Votes Far-Right in the UK? (Rounds 1-11)


What we’re looking at:
This shows differences from reference categories across nine demographic dimensions:
Reference baseline (0 line): - Female (gender reference) - Age 18-34 (age reference) - Liberal on immigration (reference) - High trust in politicians (reference) - Political center (reference) - Comfortable income (reference) - High education (reference) - Urban location (reference) - Professional/managers (reference)

Yes: Working class +, lower education +, restrictive immigration attitudes +, older voters +, rural +, low political trust +

title: Far-Right in the United Kingdom
text:
Electoral Marginality & Policy Victory (2010-2016)


The Real Paradox (not what the chart shows):
The chart shows something MECHANICAL, not paradoxical: - FPTP suppresses representation → predictable, by design - PR enables proportional representation → also predictable, by design - This is HOW these systems work, not surprising
The ACTUAL paradox is elsewhere:

Electoral marginality via FPTP (2015):

3.88 million votes (12.6%) → 1 seat
Massively unrepresented

But policy victory (2016):

Won Brexit referendum
Forced government hand
Achieved biggest political goal without parliament


This contradicts an assumption: - “Parliamentary seats = political power” - UKIP proves: Electoral marginality ≠ policy irrelevance - Non-electoral pathways (activism, public campaign, political pressure) can matter more than seats
This is genuinely puzzling: - How do parties without seats win referendums? - How do marginal parties force major policy shifts? - What does this tell us about far-right influence beyond parliament?
This will be crucial for Week 9 (normalization): Far-right influence operates through multiple channels, not just electoral representation.

section: From Strategy to System: What the UK Case Shows
text:
From Strategy to System: What the UK Case Shows

Same grievances, different party framings and images → different voter coalitions.
Same voters, different electoral rules → different representation in office.
Weak in parliament, but strong through referendums and discourse → major policy change (Brexit).


Key questions:


Which party strategies unlock broad support among those worried about immigration and Europe?
How do electoral rules and referendums channel that support into real policy outcomes?

Task Description
Write an engaging opinion piece on ANY aspect of contemporary far-right politics that interests you. This is your opportunity to explore the far-right creatively while applying course concepts.
Your topic can be anything related to the far-right, including:

Political developments (elections, coalitions, policies)
Cultural dimensions (fashion, music, symbols, aesthetics)
Social phenomena (football hooliganism, online communities, youth culture)
Gender and the far-right (masculinity, women’s roles, femonationalism)
Media and communication (social media strategies, memes, propaganda)
Historical comparisons or contemporary parallels

Your piece should:

Focus on a specific, concrete topic (not “the far-right in general”)
Apply at least 1-2 concepts or insights from what we have covered before the deadline
Make a clear argument or observation (not just description)
Be written for an educated general audience - engaging, accessible, and jargon-free
Include evidence from course materials, current events, or your own observations
Have a compelling headline that captures your argument

Think of your audience as: Guardian readers, Foreign Policy subscribers, podcast listeners, or people scrolling through The Conversation. You want to inform AND engage them.
This assessment tests your ability to:

Apply course concepts creatively to real-world phenomena
Communicate complex ideas to non-specialist audiences
Develop original analytical insights about the far-right
Write clearly, persuasively, and engagingly
You may write in first person if appropriate for your topic and argument

WHAT MAKES A GOOD OPINION PIECE?

Strong opening hook: Start with a compelling observation, recent event, or provocative question
Clear argument: What’s your main point? State it early and return to it
Concrete examples: Use specific evidence, not abstract generalities
Accessible language: Explain concepts clearly; avoid academic jargon
Engaging voice: Write like you’re explaining something interesting to a friend who’s intelligent but doesn’t study politics
Course connection: Weave in 1-2 concepts from lectures/readings naturally (don’t force them)
So what?: Why should readers care? What are the implications?

Remember: The best opinion pieces make readers think differently about something they thought they understood. Be creative, be specific, and have fun with this!

text:
Task Description
Write a comparative analytical essay that examines far-right politics across 2-3 country cases. You may choose from the provided essay questions OR propose your own question (which must be approved via your essay plan).

Your essay must fulfill the following five core requirements:

Make a clear analytical argument

Answer a specific question about why outcomes vary or when/how mechanisms work.
Go beyond description to explain patterns, test theories, or identify causal mechanisms.
Your thesis should be evident from the introduction and sustained throughout the essay.

Compare systematically across cases

Genuinely compare 2-3 cases (do not write separate country descriptions and then just bolt them together).
Choose cases that vary on the outcome you want to explain, OR that test a theory in different contexts.
Explicitly discuss similarities and differences throughout, not just in the conclusion.
Use comparison to generate analytical leverage: what does comparing these cases reveal that studying one alone would not?

Engage with course theories

Apply theoretical frameworks from Weeks 7-8 (demand-side and/or supply-side theories).
Test theoretical claims against your empirical evidence.
Evaluate competing explanations where relevant.
Show you understand both what theories predict AND their limitations.

Use specific empirical evidence

Support claims with concrete evidence from your cases (electoral data, party strategies, policy examples, timeline of events).
Draw on course readings AND additional research (use a minimum of 10 sources).
Demonstrate detailed knowledge of your chosen cases.

Write clearly and reference properly

Write for an academic audience (more formal than an opinion piece, but still clear and accessible).

Write clearly: Academic tone, properly referenced.



What Makes a Strong Comparative Essay?
Good case selection is crucial. Choose cases that:

Vary on the outcome: e.g., France had an early breakthrough, while Germany was delayed by 30 years—why?
Share similarities but differ on key variables: e.g., both are Scandinavian welfare states, but Denmark’s far-right collapsed while Sweden’s grew—why?
Test a theory in different contexts: e.g., does economic crisis drive far-right support? Test this in Greece vs. Spain.

Common pitfalls to avoid:

The “Silo” Approach: Describing each country separately, then just saying “these cases show variation” in the conclusion.
Apples and Oranges: Choosing cases that are too different to compare meaningfully (e.g., Hungary and New Zealand).
Overly Identical Cases: Choosing cases that are too similar—comparison should reveal something new, not just confirm they are alike.
Theory Dumping: Summarizing course readings without actively applying them to your specific cases.
Unsubstantiated Claims: Making claims without evidence (e.g., saying “the far-right is rising everywhere” without showing the data).

What good comparison looks like:
“While both France and Germany experienced similar immigration levels in the 1980s-90s, the National Front broke through in 1984 while no far-right party succeeded in Germany until 2013. This 30-year gap cannot be explained by demand-side factors alone…”
“Denmark and Sweden both have generous welfare states that should theoretically create opportunities for welfare chauvinist appeals. Yet Denmark’s DPP collapsed after 2019 while Sweden Democrats continued growing. The key difference lies in mainstream party responses…”
“The economic crisis hypothesis predicts that severe crises produce far-right mobilization. Greece confirms this (Golden Dawn 7% in 2012), but Spain disconfirms it (no far-right until 2018 despite similar crisis). This variation suggests…”

title: Assessment 3: Long Essay
text:
Essay Questions
You may choose from these or propose your own:

Why did far-right breakthrough occur in the 1980s in France but not until 2013 in Germany? Explain the 30-year delay with reference to historical legacies and party system factors.
How do electoral systems shape far-right party strategy and success? Compare far-right performance under FPTP (UK) versus PR systems (Netherlands, Germany, or France).
Does mainstream party accommodation of far-right positions help or hurt far-right electoral performance? Compare 2-3 cases of different mainstream responses.
Why did the 2008-2015 economic crisis produce far-right breakthrough in Greece but not Spain (until 2018)? Analyze the mechanisms linking crisis to far-right mobilization.
How does incumbent radicalization (Hungary, Poland) differ from opposition far-right parties (Western Europe) in its causes and democratic consequences?
Which mainstream party strategy is most effective at containing far-right parties: cordon sanitaire or accommodation? Compare outcomes in 2-3 cases.
Does government participation normalize or undermine far-right parties? Compare the effects of coalition participation in 2-3 cases (Norway, Finland, Austria, Italy, or Netherlands).
Why do areas with low immigration sometimes show high far-right support? Test competing explanations of the ‘immigration paradox’ using 2-3 cases.
To what extent do European theories explain far-right success in non-European contexts? Test theoretical applicability using European and non-European cases.
How do far-right parties successfully professionalize and moderate their image? Compare transformation strategies in 2-3 cases (Sweden Democrats, National Rally, or others).
Why did Denmark’s People’s Party collapse after 2019 while Sweden Democrats continued growing? Analyze the effectiveness of mainstream position accommodation strategies.

Course Description
This course offers a comprehensive exploration of the rise and persistence of far-right politics globally, with a primary focus on Europe but extending to comparative analysis of cases from, for example, the United States, Brazil, India, and Argentina. The course examines the structural transformations within democratic systems and their impact on representative politics. Through a thematic approach, students will engage with cutting-edge research to understand the complex factors driving far-right electoral success across different political and cultural contexts.

Apply insights from the contemporary analysis of the far right and interpret the evidence in a range of country studies drawn from Europe

Key Puzzles from Southern Europe

The Crisis Timing Puzzle - When economic crisis creates far-right opportunities, what determines the timing of breakthrough? Can crisis alone drive far-right success, or is something else required?
The Historical Durability Question - How long can historical legacies (regime type, founding narratives) delay or block far-right emergence? Is there a breaking point?
The Supply-Demand Relationship - Across all cases, demand for far-right politics existed before parties mobilized it. What explains when credible supply emerges to meet demand?
The Mainstream Strategy Question - Do different mainstream responses (isolation, incorporation, accommodation) permanently block far-right, or do they merely delay breakthrough?
The Path Dependency Puzzle - Does the type of regime transition (left-wing revolution vs. right-wing elite transition vs. external collapse) shape far-right trajectories for decades? If so, why?
The Convergence Question - Why do regions with dramatically different historical contexts eventually converge toward similar far-right electoral levels (15-25%)?

title: Explaining Variation in Far-Right Support
text:
Beyond Latent Demand


Demand-side (Week 7)

Grievances (Economic, Cultural, Status)
Stable anti-immigrant potential (~40–60%)
Individual-level readiness to vote far-right


Supply-side (Week 8)

Context (Structure): Electoral rules, party competition, media salience
Party (Agency): Credible organization, leadership, strategic framing



Theoretical Reality: Grievances can remain “latent” for decades without political representation (e.g., Germany 1990-2013).

title: Explaining Variation in Far-Right Support
section: The Core Puzzle: Demand without Supply?
text:
The Core Puzzle: Demand without Supply?

UK (1990s-2010s): High Euroskepticism and Nativism → 0 MPs due to FPTP system.
Spain (2008-2018): Severe Economic Crisis → No Far Right breakthrough until 2018.
Germany (1980s-2013): High Authoritarian Potential → Blocked by historical stigma and failed parties.
Scandinavia: Similar levels of cultural threat → Varied Breakthrough Timing (Denmark 1990s vs Sweden 2010).


→ Demand is a necessary condition, but Supply is the sufficient condition.

title: Explaining Variation in Far-Right Support
section: From Normal Pathology to Pathological Normalcy
text:
From Normal Pathology to Pathological Normalcy

Old View (Scheuch & Klingemann 1967): Far right as an “abnormal” pathology of extreme crisis.

Logic: Crisis → Far Right. No Crisis → No Far Right.

New View (Mudde 2010): “Pathological Normalcy”

Far-right values (Nativism, Authoritarianism) are radicalised versions of mainstream values.
These values are always present in the electorate.

The Supply-Side Shift:

Variation is explained by political opportunity structures and party agency, not the emergence of “new” grievances.

title: Explaining Variation in Far-Right Support

Political Opportunity Structures (POS)
1. Institutional Factors (The Rules of the Game)

Electoral Systems:

Proportional Representation (PR): Low entry barriers (e.g., Netherlands) → Easy entry.
Majoritarian Systems: High barriers (e.g., UK) → “Wasted vote” logic suppresses supply.

State Funding & Media Access:

Institutional support helps stabilize new parties (e.g., Germany, Belgium).

The “Convergence” Mechanism:

Discursive Opportunity Structures (DOS)
It is not just about rules, but about Public Visibility. Koopmans & Olzak (2004):

Visibility: Does the media prioritize the party’s issues? (e.g., immigration).
Resonance: Does the party’s frame “make sense” given everyday reality?
Legitimacy: Is the actor treated as a valid participant in debate?



Issue Ownership & Salience: - Far-right parties “own” immigration.

Breakthroughs happen when external shocks (e.g., 2015 Refugee Crisis) spike issue salience.

title: Explaining Variation in Far-Right Support

The Non-Inevitability of Success
Far-right breakthroughs are not structurally guaranteed. Success can be halted by:

Strategic Containment: When mainstream right parties successfully absorb far-right factions (e.g., Spain’s PP before 2013).
Supply Implosion: Incompetence or scandal destroying the vehicle (e.g., BNP in UK, Republicans in Germany).
The “Government Curse”: Moderation in office leading to collapse (e.g., LAOS in Greece, Blue Reform in Finland).
Institutional Stigma: Strong civic education or judicial intervention (e.g., Golden Dawn).

The Interaction: Supply factors (Rules, Strategy, Organisation) explain why similar demand profiles produce wildly different outcomes.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
The Core Puzzle

The Observation: Across Europe, Mainstream Parties (MSPs) have tried everything to stop the Far-Right.
The Strategies: They have ignored them, attacked them, and copied them.
The Outcome: The Far-Right has moved from the “lunatic fringe” to the centre of power.
The Question: Why do “rational” strategies by powerful mainstream parties fail to stop—and often accelerate—this process?

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Analytical Framework

We will examine three core dimensions of the normalization process.
Dimension I: Strategic Competition (The Rational Actor vs. Empirical Reality)
Dimension II: Information Environments (The Role of Media in Shaping Preferences)
Dimension III: Temporal Dynamics (Stigmatization and Path Dependence)

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Theory A: The Spatial Logic (Meguid 2005, 2008)

Premise: Politics is a market. Parties compete for voters on issues.
The Problem: A niche party (Far-Right) owns a new issue (Immigration).
The Solution (Accommodation): The Mainstream Centre-Right (MCR) should adopt the niche party’s position.
The Mechanism:

MCR steals “ownership” of the issue.
Voters, seeing identical policies, choose the large, competent MCR over the risky niche party.
Result: Niche party collapses.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
section: The Empirical Reality Check (Krause et al. 2023)
text:
The Empirical Reality Check (Krause et al. 2023)

The Test: Analyzed 350+ mainstream strategies across 12 Western European countries (1976-2017).
The Question: Does adopting anti-immigration positions reduce Far-Right votes?
The Finding: No.

Accommodation does not reduce Radical Right support.
In fact, it often increases voter transfers to the Radical Right.

The Mechanism: Voters prefer the “original” to the “copy” (Jean-Marie Le Pen).
Key Takeaway: You cannot beat the Far-Right by becoming them.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
section: Does it work? The Case of the UK
text:
Does it work? The Case of the UK

Scenario: UKIP threatens the Conservative Party (2010s).
Strategy: Conservatives adopt UKIP’s core demand (EU Referendum/Brexit).
Electoral Outcome: UKIP vote collapses (2017/2019).
Verdict: Meguid appears right only if we look at the party label.
BUT: As Krause et al. suggest, this is the exception, not the rule. And the ideological cost was total.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Theory B: The Legitimacy Trap (Daur 2024)

The Counter-Argument: Accommodating a “Pariah” (outcast) party isn’t just a policy shift; it’s a moral signal.
The Experiment: Daur (2024) shows that when MSPs adopt Far-Right positions or cooperate, they signal that the Far-Right is “appropriate, proper, and just.”
The “Validation” Effect:

Voters update their beliefs: “If the Prime Minister says it, it can’t be racist.”
Legitimacy extends beyond the MSP’s own voters.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Synthesis: The “Success” Paradox

The Double Failure:

Electoral: You often fail to destroy the party. Krause et al. (2023) show accommodation often helps the Far-Right.
Normative: Even if the party dies (e.g., UKIP), you normalise the ideology (Brexit is law).

The Trap: By accommodating, you lower the “reputational cost” of Far-Right ideas.
Valentim (2021): This is amplified by Representation.

Crossing the threshold (5%) into Parliament acts as an institutional “Seal of Approval.”
Radical views become publicly acceptable because they are present in the House.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Theory A: The “Mirror” Hypothesis

Premise: Media and parties just “reflect” what the people want (Demand-Side).
Argument: The Far-Right rises because people are already worried about immigration. The media just reports it.
Implication: Censoring the Far-Right or the media wouldn’t change the underlying demand.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
section: Theory B: The Media as “Maker” (Foos & Bischof 2022)
text:
Theory B: The Media as “Maker” (Foos & Bischof 2022)

The Study: A natural experiment in the UK.
The Event: The Liverpool boycott of The Sun (tabloid) after the Hillsborough disaster (1989).
The Findings:

Merseyside (boycott area) became significantly less Eurosceptic than comparable areas.
Why? Because they weren’t exposed to decades of anti-EU crusade by The Sun.

The Implication: The media doesn’t just mirror demand; it manufactures it.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Connect to Normalisation

If media campaigns can drive Euroscepticism (as Foos & Bischof show), what happens when mainstream media treats the Far-Right as “normal”?
Media Mainstreaming:

Giving them a platform (BBC “Question Time” effect).
Adopting their frames (“Mass Migration” vs. “Refugee Crisis”).

Conclusion: Normalisation happens before the vote is even cast, in the pages of the tabloids.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Theory A: The “Thermostat” (Re-Stigmatisation)

Premise: If accommodation fails, MSPs can just switch back to Isolation (Cordon Sanitaire).
Logic: “We tried talking to them, it didn’t work, now we will ostracise them again.”
Assumption: Stigma is a switch you can turn on and off.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
section: Theory B: The “One-Way Street” (Balcells et al. 2025)
text:
Theory B: The “One-Way Street” (Balcells et al. 2025)

The Experiment: Can you re-stigmatise a party (like Vox in Spain) after it has been normalised?
The Finding: No.
Once the taboo is broken, attempts to re-impose stigma fail or backfire.
Why?

Voters have already seen the party as a legitimate partner.
Calling them “undemocratic” now sounds like a strategic lie, not a moral truth.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
The “Stimulus” Effect (Ammassari 2024)

Pre-Normalisation: Stigma works. It scares off moderate voters (Social Desirability Bias).
Post-Normalisation: Stigma fails.

For core supporters, attacks from the mainstream act as a stimulus.
“They hate us because we tell the truth.”

The Result: The “Cordon Sanitaire” only works if you never break it. Once broken, it cannot be repaired.

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
The Grand Puzzle for Discussion

The Rational Trap:

If you ignore them → Media might amplify them (Foos & Bischof).
If you accommodate them → You legitimise their ideas (Daur) and often lose votes (Krause et al.).
If you attack them → You might stimulate their base (Ammassari).

Discussion Q1: Is there any successful strategy for a Mainstream Party today?
Discussion Q2: Look at your case study. Did the “Cordon Sanitaire” break? If so, did it follow the “One-Way Street” logic?

title: The Normalisation of the Far-Right
text:
Key Takeaways

Meguid’s Model is flawed: Empirical evidence shows accommodation rarely works (Krause et al.) and ignores normative legitimacy.
Media matters: It shapes the battlefield before the battle begins (Foos & Bischof).
Irreversibility: Normalisation is a ratchet mechanism. It creates a new baseline for what is “acceptable” in democracy.
